To my L. Trea

Belgia: 1591 Octo
b
r
May it please yo
r
good L. to be advertised that uppon
e sight of a
letter from
e LL. of the Counsell of
e 7 of this moneth and of
an other from yo
r
L. of
e 8 w
ch
I found at
e Hage, at my returne
from Nieumeghen, I have had some conference w
t
the States about
e amendement of their Placart, for their trafficke w
t
e Ennemie.
Howbeit they consulted uppon it before I returned, having had from M
r
Caron
e considerations of the pointes w
ch
were delivered from
e LL.
And as in every other matter, that is of any weight, it is the course of their
government, not to take a resolution w
t
out
e privitie of their Principals,
so they say in this matter, they will impart it to
e Provinces, and answear
it assoone as conveniently they may. And because their present answear
doth import nothing els, w
ch
is not worthy of a letter, to
e LL. of
e Counsel,
I shall humblie beseeche you to report it for me. Moreover I am
required by
e LL. to demaund a fuller answear, to all suche matters as
were proposed at M
r
Wilkes being heere: w
ch
I have not yet perfourmed,
desiring by your L. to understand once againe their pleasures therin. For
I knowe they will calle uppon me, to signifie w
t
pointes are most misliked
by her Ma
tie
and will require a full replie to every article of their
answear. For in effect, it was all rejected w
at
seover was demaunded.
And if that be the meaninge of their LL. that I shall make
at Replie,
I will first contrive it heere, and after send it home to be changed in suche
sorte, as their LL. shall see cause. Nevertheles if your L. will be plea
sed to heare my opinion, I doe assure my selfe,
at I shall never prevaile
by replieinge unto them, unles her Hig
nes
w
t
drawing some part of her
assistaunce from hens. Before w
ch
time, for her Ma
tie
to attempt
any one thinge often, and to obtene nothinge at any time, but still to be
refused, and to beare it w
th
patience, it is to encourage them greatly, to
persist in their courses. Moreover to my simple seeminge, it is no fitte
opportunitie, to enter farre w
th
this people in any bitter contestation, by
reason of these motions, whiche are towardes about a peace. So as for
mine owne part, consideringe that their warres are happely conducted, I
shoulde earnestly incline, to recommend unto her Ma
tie
some littell
longer tolleration. God hath blessed of late their martial endeavours,
in a wonderfull manner, that if the townes of Steenwicke, Boisleduke, and
Gertrudenbergh were recovered, wherof the hope is very great in the
next Sommers service, undoubtedly these Provinces would rest in great
assurance. And if it sould so happen, or also otherwise,
e Frenche
Kinges affaires going prosperously forward, her Ma
tie
in my conceat, may
spare all the charges of her forces heere in feilde: and ether put them over
to be paied by the States, in part or in whole, or if the States be
unwilling, to be presently cassed. For when the Country is once assured,
there is no suche daunger of the Enemy, but
at w
th
those forces, w
ch
they
have nowe in esse, they wilbe able well enough to defend their Country:
or if they be not, their generall meanes will suffice to increase their nom-
bers, to as many as her Ma
tie
will defalke. This day
fol.237v
Belgia: 1591: Oc
t
there is made by the Counsell of State an earnest proposition to
e general
States, w
ch
is to be imparted to every Province and towne, for an extra
ordinary Contribution, to the summe of nintie thowsande poundes sterling
for the levieng of newe forces
e next spring; and
at the mony may be
receaved, by the General Receavor of the Countrey, to be dispensed by
the Councel of State. They doe not make any doubt, but
at
e
Provinces will yeelde unto it. I have bin written to of late by Joes
Van Cleve (w
ch
is
e party by whose practise and meanes I dealt
e last
yere w
t
those of Groeninghen) who informeth me as muche as I write
unto your L.
e 4 of this moneth, that the people w
th
in the towne are
greatly distracted, not knowing w
ch
way to bend their course. For some
are very willing to present themselves unto her Ma
tie
and some are
more desirous to accord w
th
the States, as also the Spaniard hath
a great many favourers. In this their perplexitie I have followed
e advise of Joes Van Cleve, who hath wished me to addresse an other
letter to
e Magistrats and Commons of the towne; w
ch
I have don
to suche purpose, as yo
r
L. may see by the copie in Englishe, w
ch
I sent
to them in Dutche; w
ch
I trust is so indited, as if it turne her Ma
tie
to no benefit, it cannot prejudice her honor or service in any thing. I
have not imparted it heere to any of the States, findinge heeretofore
by their jalouse proceedinges, that neither they are desirous, that
e
towne shoulde come under her Ma
ties
obeissance, nor that themselves
should recover it by her Ma
ties
autoritie. Concerninge the
affaires at touche the Gouvernor of Ostend, I followed
at direction
at yo
r
L. gave, w
ch
was to signifie to himselfe, wherw
t
he was charg
ed
by the States. Now it seemeth by your letter of the 8 of this mon
th
at your L. doth require e particular verifications of the pointes at I
proposed. But as I writte unto your L. when I sent you the copie,
of that I writte unto the Gouvernor, I did but certefie suche matters
as I conceaved of my selfe to be most materiall, thinkinge if his
answer
had bin any thinge pertinent, to have done my best endeavor for appe
[as]
ing the States. To set downe every proofe, of every matter in partic
ular
I could not conveniently w
t
out the privitie of this Counsell, who had
the custody of all suche notes. Againe to say truly, I never thoug
ht
at
e Gouvernor woulde have stoode uppon denial of any mater of Fa
ct
but excused rather his proceedinges, w
t
his good intention and well mean
ing
But nowe
at your L. hath receaved his answear, the truthe of every
point will appeare upon replie. Whiche if your L. will be pleased to
require of this Councel, I shall not be so subject to some privat displeasures
of
the Gouvernor or his frindes. Nevertheles I must crave of yo
r
L. to
pardon in this case my confident writing: for I must say, as I doe finde
by very manifest proofe,
at unles there be some error in a peece of an arti
cle
or in a matter of circumstance, the substance of the whole, wherw
t
he is cha
rged
will never be reprooved. And this I knowe in the end will so appe
are
unto your L. For I am otherwise of my self so thouroughly acquainted
w
t
the clamorous humor of
e Officers of the States against the
actions
in speciall of those of o
r
nation, as I credit them in nothing, unles I
finde it
evident, as there can be no evasion. Of the Enemie
s endeavors
we learne by a letter of
e Duke of Parma, w
ch
was lately
intercepted, being
fol.238r
Belgia: 1591: Octo
b
r
written to Verdugo, that the mutines of Diest have receaved contentment.
And by letters from Brussels we are newly advertised,
at
e Duke is
willed, by a freshe commaundement out of Spaine, all exceptions sett a part
to goe presently for Fraunce. It is signified w
t
all,
at
e Ambassadors
of peace, have bin at Collen already, and are expected now at Brussells.
There is come out of Zeland advertisment, that
e Enemy doth fortifie neere
unto Hulst: in a dorpe w
ch
is called St Jans Steen. Wherupon the
States of Zeland have sent hither for some succor of horse and foote. For
the Enemie, doth intend, if his purpose be not letted, to barre us wholy from
comming to the Land of Waes.
&c./
